content.question:
​

<math alttext="x"><mi>x</mi></math>
<math alttext="5"><mn>5</mn></math>
<math alttext="6"><mn>6</mn></math>
<math alttext="7"><mn>7</mn></math>
<math alttext="8"><mn>8</mn></math>
<math alttext="9"><mn>9</mn></math>
<math alttext="10"><mn>10</mn></math>
<math alttext="f open parentheses x close parentheses"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math>
<math alttext="negative 17"><mo>-</mo><mn>17</mn></math>
<math alttext="negative 27"><mo>-</mo><mn>27</mn></math>
<math alttext="negative 39"><mo>-</mo><mn>39</mn></math>
<math alttext="negative 53"><mo>-</mo><mn>53</mn></math>
<math alttext="negative 69"><mo>-</mo><mn>69</mn></math>
<math alttext="negative 87"><mo>-</mo><mn>87</mn></math>
​
​The table gives values for the function <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> at selected values of <math alttext="x"><mi>x</mi></math>. Which of the following conclusions with reason is consistent with the values in the table?

choices.label: ​The graph of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> is concave up because the average rate of change over consecutive equal-length intervals is increasing.
​The graph of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> is concave up because the average rate of change over consecutive equal-length intervals is decreasing.
​The graph of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> is concave down because the average rate of change over consecutive equal-length intervals is increasing.
​The graph of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> is concave down because the average rate of change over consecutive equal-length intervals is decreasing.

content.answer: ​The graph of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> is concave down because the average rate of change over consecutive equal-length intervals is decreasing.

topic.text: 1.3: Rates of Change in Linear and Quadratic Functions

skill.text: Skill 3.C: Support conclusions or choices with a logical rationale or appropriate data.
